description: From Middle English replyen, replien, borrowed from Old French replier (“to reply”), from the Latin replicō, replicāre (“I fold back”) (in Late or Medieval Latin "to reply, repeat"), from re + plicō (“I fold”); the noun derives from the verb by nominalisation. Doublet of replicate and replica.

entries.meaning: A written or spoken response; part of a conversation.
(US, law) A document written by a party specifically replying to a responsive declaration and in some cases an answer.

verbs.description: reply (third-person singular simple present replies, present participle replying, simple past and past participle replied)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To give a written or spoken response, especially to a question, request, accusation or criticism; to answer.
examples: (transitive) He replied that he was not sure.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To act or gesture in response.
examples: Joanne replied to Pete's insult with a slap to his face.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To repeat something back; to echo.
